       Refusal to order separate trial (Ghanem 5) 
       
      
    119 Ghanem’s application for a separate trial was refused on 8 March 2002. It had been made on the basis of a weak case against the particular accused; prejudice stemming particularly from the pervert course of justice charges against Bilal Skaf; Ghanem’s non-involvement in other attacks about which evidence would be given; and prejudice that would occur if any co-accused gave evidence. 
     
      
       
      
    120 Judge Finnane held that the three series of attacks on the complainant were linked in that they occurred one after the other with the same victim seemingly being handed over from one group to the next. He considered the weight of evidence against Ghanem as compared to that implicating the other accused. He held that the identification evidence seemed to be quite clear and that the strength of the case against Ghanem was not affected by that implicating others. He was of the opinion that there was no evidence that was highly prejudicial to Ghanem although inadmissible against him. In forming this view, he observed that the material suggesting perversion of the course of justice by the Skaf brothers reflected only on those who were part of it. Other factors taken into account were concern that quite a false picture would be created if the complainant did not give evidence of all of the events that occurred; the expense and inconvenience that would be caused in bringing large numbers of witnesses to more than one trial; and the interests of the complainant.121 Ghanem accepts that the issue to be determined in this Court is whether the trial miscarried because it was unfair to have a joint trial in all the circumstances (see generally Verma (1987) 30 A Crim R 441). 
     
      
       
      
    122 In our view the trial involving Ghanem did not miscarry on this ground. The interests of justice made it appropriate for there to be a joint trial. As it turned out, the complainant’s credibility was tested on particular issues as she gave her account of a related stream of events. For example, the circumstances of one contested identification were available to be compared with another identification that was in dispute. The complainant’s account of who was present at various stages of the horrific evening, particularly stages where one of the accused was directly involved, had to be given and would have been tested in any event. 
     
      
       
      
    123 Proper directions were given as to the need to consider the cases separately. 
     
      
       
      
    124 It also turned out that Ghanem was the only accused to give evidence at the trial. And (for what it was worth) Chami’s ERISP (which went into evidence in his case alone) asserted that Ghanem was not present. 
     
      
       
      
    125 In our view this ground fails. 
     
      
       
        
       Belated disclosure of H’s statement (Chami 8, Ghanem 7) 
       
      
    126 Early on the morning of Thursday 23 May 2002 the defence parties were provided with a previously unserved statement of H. It was dated 14 September 2000 and it provided H's version of events involving the complainant. The Crown had closed its case the previous day. 
     
      
       
      
    127 Counsel for Chami (Ms Francis) sought an adjournment to consider what to do. After discussion the matter was stood down until midday for preliminary inquiries to be made. Upon resumption, Ms Francis applied for a further adjournment to investigate certain matters revealed by the Crown in the interim relevant to the credibility of the material in H's statement. Counsel for Ghanem (Ms Langley) sought the discharge of the jury, alternatively for leave to cross examine the complainant further. 
     
      
       
      
    128 The matter of concern was H's assertion that he was present when the complainant had been picked up from the Marion Street car park after the first set of assaults and driven by two men in a "red Mazda two door" to "some markets in a carpark". The significance in relation to Chami's and Ghanem's cases was that the complainant had in her first statement to the police described a number of assaults, including the production of the gun, as having occurred in the “red…hatchback with two doors” in which she had been driven from the Marion St carpark to the Bankstown Trotting Club. In her second statement and in her evidence, the complainant said that she was mistaken in her first statement and that it was a black two door hatchback in which she had been driven from Marion Street to the Bankstown Trotting Club. She also said that the gun was produced in the later red car, not the black car. The red car had four doors and offences involving the appellants Chami, Ghanem and Bilal Skaf were said to have occurred in it. 
     
      
       
      
    129 Judge Finnane agreed to adjourn the trial until the following Monday, explaining why he was not disposed to discharge the jury and why a limited adjournment was adequate to ensure a fair trial (Tr pp942-4). It was indicated that the defence would have the opportunity of further cross-examining the complainant and of issuing subpoenas, notwithstanding his Honour's concerns about a fishing expedition. 
     
      
       
      
    130 Before the hearing was adjourned, the Crown recalled Detective Sergeant Porta on the voir dire to give evidence about police investigations responsive to the matters raised by H in his statement. The officer was cross examined by Ms Francis and Ms Langley. 
     
      
       
      
    131 When the trial resumed the following Monday, Detective Sergeant Porta gave further evidence in the absence of the jury and he produced the documents that had previously been called for by the representatives of the accused. 
     
      
       
      
    132 Ms Francis then sought the discharge of the jury on the basis of inadequate Crown disclosure that had affected the fairness of the trial in respect of Chami. Counsel indicated that she did not wish to have the complainant recalled. Ms Langley also sought a discharge on behalf of Ghanem, indicating a similar attitude as regards the opportunity for further cross-examination of the complainant. 
     
      
       
      
    133 The applications to discharge the jury were refused. This ruling is the subject of these grounds of appeal by Chami and Ghanem. 
     
      
       
      
    134 To understand the issues it is necessary to consider the material in the complainant’s first statement, the material in H's statement, the arguments advanced at trial and pressed on appeal as to the nature of the prejudice occasioned to the accused, the material established by and during the course of Detective Sergeant Porta's voir dire evidence and the reasons given for the refusal of the application. 
     
      
       
      
    135 In her first statement to the police the complainant had said that she was driven away from the Marion Street car park in a “grungy” red hatchback with two doors. She made several corrections in her second statement. One of them was to assert that it was a black car that drove her from the Marion Street car park to the Bankstown Trotting Club car park. Her second statement and trial testimony were also to the effect that the red car in which several sexual assaults occurred and the gun was produced had four doors. There was a lot of cross-examination about discrepancies and confusion concerning the red and black cars and the description of the driver of the red car (Tr pp 260, 267, 268, 277, 278, 281). 
     
      
       
      
    136 H's statement was exculpatory of any criminal conduct. It was thus at variance with his own plea of guilty which had earlier been accepted by the judge, to the knowledge of the present appellants. The Crown prosecutor was not challenged as to her decision not to call H as a Crown witness, having regard to his unreliability. Nor was it disputed that evidence had been provided to his Honour in sentencing proceedings that indicated that H suffered from intellectual disability. H's statement contained nothing that directly assisted the cases of the two accused. Its belated production was not said to have been deliberate. 
     
      
       
      
    137 Counsel for Chami submitted to the trial judge and in this Court that H had raised the possibility of a second red car (described by H as a “real shit box”) different from the four-door red Pulsar owned by Chami in which sexual intercourse involving Chami admittedly took place. The argument was that the possibility of there being two red cars opened the way for Chami to distance himself from the complainant's evidence that the driver of the red car took a gun out of the glove box and brandished it. (The production of the gun was part of the evidence supporting the detain for advantage charge based upon several events in (Chami’s) red car.) 
     
      
       
      
    138 Counsel for Ghanem took a different position, both at trial and in this Court. H's statement was said to have revived the possibility that the complainant was correct the first time when she said that she was taken from the Marion Street carpark in a two door red hatchback. It was true that Ghanem was not alleged at any time (not even by H) to have been a passenger in the first car, and that it was at all times alleged that he arrived at the Trotting Club in the red car driven by Chami. Nevertheless, it was argued that the new material in H's statement could have been used as a basis of challenging the complainant's general credibility. 
     
      
       
      
    139 As indicated, counsel for neither accused took up the offered opportunity for further cross-examination of the complainant. That offer was made by the Crown prosecutor. The judge had his doubts, but the matter never arose for decision in light of the position taken by the two accused. Ms Langley argued that it would do injustice to her client’s case to be required to retrace her steps in light of the material in the belatedly-produced statement.140 Detective Sergeant Porta gave evidence and produced records referable to police investigations of H's claim that a “real shit box” two door red Mazda driven by a mate called Khalid or Ahmed who went to Condell Park High School gave the complainant a lift, stopping at McDonalds Bankstown. Investigations at the High School disclosed that Ahmed and Khalid were common names. No red “two door shit box” was seen at the school, which was checked over a number of days (Tr pp 949-950). There was no video surveillance tape made and/or retained at any of the public places at which the vehicle stopped en route. 
     
      
       
      
    141 The officer’s evidence showed that the information provided by H (for what it was worth) was investigated and had produced nothing of relevance.  
     
      
       
      
    142 In the upshot, the accused were given the period between Thursday and Monday to make further inquiries of their own. It is very difficult to conceive what inquiries could have been done that were not available to be done in the time permitted. The trail was obviously very cold. 
     
      
       
      
    143 In his reasons of 27 May 2002 refusing a discharge Judge Finnane referred to the fact that H had pleaded guilty to offences against the present complainant as well as offences against other persons. He was developmentally delayed. His Honour then analysed the material in H's statement, including what he said about the red car. The judge observed that most of the statement was completely false in light of H’s plea of guilty. Reference was made to the extensive cross-examination of the complainant earlier in the trial about the changes from her first statement of 1 September to her second statement of 21 September following discussion with Senior Constable Brazel on 14 September. The judge noted that it had been put to the complainant a number of times that the assaults involving Chami and later Ghanem might have taken place in a black vehicle, and that the complainant had denied this and said that they occurred in Chami's red car. The judge then referred to the evidence of Sergeant Porta about the ultimately fruitless attempts to establish the existence of the red vehicle referred to in H's statement. He concluded that the nonproduction of this information could not materially have affected the credibility of the complainant. He continued: 
     
      
       
        
         
         In my opinion this material could not be said to have any relevance or any worth. The material is contained in a false statement by a person who has pleaded guilty. It could not be put as a matter of fact by either counsel who might wish to rely on it, and calling him would not establish it as a fact because he has pleaded guilty since he made the statement. 
         
        
        
         
         In my opinion this statement is no more relevant than the supposition that anybody might come up with that there may have been another car or cars around the place at some time, notwithstanding the evidence that there was not. The fact that Mr [H], in a false statement, claims that there was a car driven by mysterious persons who cannot be really identified, nor can the car, does not, in my opinion, raise any fact of any significance or relevance or bearing upon this case. 
         
        
        
         
         I am unable to agree that any forensic advantage has been lost and I am unable to agree in any way that there has been an unfair trial because this material was not produced. In my opinion the police have no obligation, nor has the Crown, to produce every statement made by someone, even a co-accused, in a case such as this, particularly where it is obvious that what is said is false. 
         
        
        
         
        
       
      
    144 The judge referred to the remarks of King CJ in an unreported South Australian case (R v K (1991) 161 LSJS 135 at 140, cited in R v Lewis-Hamilton (1997) 92 A Crim R 532 at 537) relevant to the Crown's duty of disclosure. The Chief Justice had said: 
     
      
       
        
         
         This obligation  
         [of disclosure] 
          must in principle extend… to any information in the possession of the prosecution which reflects materially upon the credibility of prosecution witnesses. There must be limits, however, to the type of information which must be disclosed. It cannot be that the prosecution is required to disclose every speculative and scurrilous rumour which may have come to the ears of investigating officers concerning a witness. The obligation arises … only if the information is sufficiently solid to cause reasonable persons conducting the prosecution to think that cross-examination based upon it might elicit answers materially affecting the credibility of the witness. 
         
        
        
         
           
         
        
       
      
    145 These two appellants submit that the judge was wrong to have regarded H's statement as having no relevance or materiality. We are inclined to agree and are troubled by the categorical terms of His Honour's remarks. But those remarks fall into somewhat clearer focus when it is recognised that the question at issue was the impact of the material in H's statement upon the complainant's credibility.  
     
      
       
      
    146 There was no question of calling H as a witness at trial. The prosecutor's decision not to rely upon H's testimony had not been questioned and it remained open to any defendant to call H as his witness. The reality was that no one wanted him at the trial. 
     
      
       
      
    147 H’s statement opened up the possibility that a second red car driven by two of his mates was present at Bankstown early in the evening. The complainant got into the car, but no offences occurred in it, according to H. The police had followed this lead and got nowhere. The trail was very cold by the time of the trial, and the prospect that it might produce something of assistance to the defence remained speculative to the point of nonexistence.  
     
      
       
      
    148 The whole burden of the application for discharge rested upon the loss of opportunity to have used the information in H's statement in the earlier cross-examination of the complainant. The Crown prosecutor was willing to recall the complainant if necessary, but this offer was not taken up. Instead, it was argued that some material advantage had been lost earlier in the trial when the cross-examination had been framed on the basis of a defence case that had not had access to H's statement.  
     
      
       
      
    149 The suggestion that defence counsel were led down some path resulting in a miscarriage is however speculation without foundation. The principles of the Queen's Case ((1820) 2 Brod & Bing 284, 129 ER 976) as reformulated in s44 of the Evidence Act meant that the manner in which the complainant could have been confronted with the statement was severely constrained. So severely, that it was highly unlikely that defence counsel would ever have taken the risk of bringing H into the picture or putting his statement before the complainant. The opportunity to put a two red car hypothesis before the complainant by way of further cross-examination was one that counsel decided not to take up.  
     
      
       
      
    150 We do not agree that the judge erred in his refusal to discharge the jury. We agree with the main thrust of his remarks which were directed at the conclusion that no forensic advantage had been lost such as to have caused the trial to miscarry at that stage. 
     
      
       
      
    151 These grounds fail. 
     
      
       
        
       Wrongful admission of Ghanem’s photoboard identification (Ghanem 1) 
        
       
      
    152 The complainant did not mention a person with a ponytail in her first statement made on 1 September 2000. 
     
      
       
      
    153 On 14 September 2000 the complainant had a conversation with Senior Constable Brazel. The officer’s record of the description of the passenger in the red car was (Tr p551) “long hair in ponytail, wavy hair, brown, blond, Leb. 18 years, medium build, Hawaiian shirt with cargo pants”. 
     
      
       
      
    154 The next description given by the complainant was in her statement of 21 September 2000 (Tr p303): 
     
      
       
        
         
         … male, of Lebanese appearance. He was aged about 18 years, he wore his hair in a ponytail, his hair was slightly curly on the ends. He was medium build wearing an Hawaiian shirt and bone coloured cargo pants. 
         
        
        
       
      
    155 On 15 November 2000 the complainant identified Ghanem from a photoboard comprising 15 photographs (Ex C6). He is not the only young man with longish hair, but his was the only photograph depicting a man with obviously long hair which was blondish and curly on the ends. (When the police had attended Ghanem’s home he took his hair out of a ponytail before he was photographed with it hanging loose.) 
     
      
       
      
    156 In her evidence in chief the complainant described the front passenger of the red car (Ghanem, on the Crown case) in the following terms (Tr p83): 
     
      
       
        
         
         Q. Now you mentioned the passenger, and I don’t think I have asked you, what did the passenger look like? 
          
         A. Well, what I remembered about him, he was actually good looking. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. This is the front seat passenger of the red car? 
          
         A. Yes. I remember thinking why did he feel the need to do this to me when he could have found any girl to do it with him. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. Because he was attractive? 
          
         A. That’s what struck me. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. What did he look like? 
          
         A. He had - I remember his hair, it was blondish at the ends, he had it long, like an undercut sort of, and he was wearing, had it in a pony-tail, and I remember him wearing a Hawaiian kind of shirt and a pair of bone cargo pants. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. How long was his hair; did you notice? 
          
         A. When it was tied up it was just past the nape of his neck. It was fairly long for a guy, I remember. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. Yes. Was it curly or straight or -- 
          
         A. It was curly at the ends. It was pulled back really tight, so the top was really straight, but it was curly at the ends. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. Did you see his face well, or not? 
          
         A. Yes. While he was doing that assault upon me I remember looking at his face a few times, because it was only inches away from mine, so I did get quite a few good looks at his face. It was one of the faces that stuck in my mind the most after that night. 
         
        
        
       See also Tr pp293, 315, 359-60, 440 for further evidence of the complainant on this issue. 
        
       
      
    157 The complainant agreed in cross-examination that the hair was what stood out most of all in her mind in her identification of Ghanem. But she adhered to her evidence about other features, including his deep set eyes and the fact that he was “somewhat better looking”. 
     
      
       
      
    158 The police search of Ghanem’s home revealed no Hawaiian shirt or bone coloured cargo pants. In his evidence denying any involvement in the sexual assault of the complainant, Ghanem said that he did not own any such clothing. 
     
      
       
      
    159 The submission on appeal is that the photoboard identification was unfairly prejudicial and ought to have been excluded. It’s admission at trial had been objected to on this basis (Tr pp361-70). The point being made was that, of the 15 photos in the particular photoboard, there was only one person who fitted the description then previously given as to the passenger in the red car. 
     
      
       
      
    160 One difficulty with this submission is that it would confine the relevant array to the particular photoboard containing Ghanem’s picture. But this was not a case where the complainant was asked to look at a particular photoboard to see if she could identify a particular person. The complainant viewed five photoboards over three separate visits, sometimes identifying one or more of the young men pictured. 
     
      
       
      
    161 In brief reasons given on 7 May 2002 Judge Finnane ruled that the evidence was not unfairly prejudicial and he refused to exclude it. He held that all the men depicted in Ex C6 appear to have been roughly in the same age group and could be said to have a Middle Eastern or Lebanese appearance. All had different facial characteristics. Apart from Ghanem, there were ten persons whose hair could be said to be long enough to wear in a ponytail. None of the persons in the photographs were shown to be wearing ponytails, including Ghanem. His Honour then recounted the various statements given by the complainant describing the passenger in the red car (with the exception of the statement made to Senior Constable Brazel, which had not at that stage been elicited in evidence). 
     
      
       
      
    162 After referring to s137 of the Evidence Act his Honour focussed on the submission that showing the photoboards to the witness had created unfair prejudice to the accused because he was so different from others pictured in it. He observed that the complainant’s identification of the accused was not confined to selecting the photo. There was a video showing how she came to pick the particular photo and there was nothing to suggest that she had been prompted in any way to select a particular photo. She and others gave evidence about the whole identification process. 
     
      
       
      
    163 His Honour observed (correctly) that the test in question was not whether the evidence was prejudicial but whether it was unfairly prejudicial. On that test, he refused to exclude the evidence. He observed that the photoboard evidence had been supplemented by other evidence that would have to be assessed by the jury in light of directions given to them. 
     
      
       
      
    164 We have looked at Ex C6. There is no reason to disagree with Judge Finnane’s factual conclusions in relation to the various photographs depicted in it. Nor do we detect any error in the trial judge’s approach to the balancing task with which he was confronted on this particular issue. 
     
      
       
      
    165 The Crown accepts that Ghanem’s hair in the photograph is lighter than that of any of the other young men pictured in Ex C6, but submits that it is not significantly lighter. We agree that it is not significantly lighter than the hair of the men in pictures 3 and 5. In any event, the colour of the hair was not a significant aspect of the identification process. 
     
      
       
      
    166 The case is far removed from Blick (2000) 111 A Crim R 326 upon which the appellant placed some reliance. There the photoboard showed only one man with a goatee beard and that had been the sole identifying factor in the witness’ mind. 
     
      
       
      
    167 Ghanem does not suggest any misconduct on the part of the police in compiling the particular photoboard that became Ex C6. The police had to work within the confines of the complainant’s description of the various suspects. Naturally, there had to be a bona fide and reasonable attempt to provide a fair array. None of the accused had agreed to a line up. 
     
      
       
      
    168 This ground fails. 
     
      
       
        
       Wrongful admission of Ghanem’s telephone intercept evidence (Ghanem 3) 
        
       
      
    169 Chami was interviewed by the police on 13 October 2000. When the interview was largely complete Chami was permitted to leave the police station. During this break he made four telephone calls which were intercepted and recorded. Two were calls to Ghanem. 
     
      
       
      
    170 Some of Chami’s statements were clearly incriminatory of himself. The present ground of appeal concerns whether they were properly left to the jury on the basis of being incriminatory of Ghanem. 
     
      
       
      
    171 The transcript of the calls is Ex C41. It reveals a conversation between two friends one of whom (Chami) is very concerned that he is about to be charged with serious offences involving the present complainant. In Chami’s words, “Ghanem, they’ve fucked me, brother”. The two men made arrangements to meet urgently at the Bankstown library. 
     
      
       
      
    172 Ghanem’s responses were consistent with concern for a friend who had got himself into trouble with the police, but the real issue is whether they revealed more. In his evidence, Ghanem confirmed that he had been a friend of Chami since kindergarten, that he had heard that police visited Chami’s home and that he was concerned to comfort a friend who was upset as a result of his interview with the police (Tr pp979-81, 1017-8, 1020). He said in effect that he had no other purpose: if he was worried, it was worry about his friend. 
     
      
       
      
    173 The prosecution sought to adduce the telephone calls as evidence of consciousness of guilt against both Chami and Ghanem. At trial Ghanem’s counsel objected on the grounds of relevance and invoked ss135 and 137 of the Evidence Act. 
     
      
       
      
    174 One portion of the conversation was: 
     
      
       
        
         
         Chami: [They know your name] I’ve seen Bill’s name, everyone’s name [They know everything] bro 
         
        
        
         
         Ghanem: So what’s gunna happen? 
         
        
        
         
         Chami: …I’m at the cop shop. 
         
        
        
       
      
    175 Judge Finnane ruled that the evidence was admissible to show consciousness of guilt on the part of Chami. But in relation to Ghanem, his Honour ruled that it could not be used for this purpose. Nevertheless, the evidence was available to show “close association” or “deep interest in what Mr Chami is talking about or had talked about” or “an association between two people having an interest in the matter which is the subject of the trial” (Reasons 16 May 2002 pp9-10). 
     
      
       
      
    176 Ghanem submits that the evidence should not have been admitted against him on this or any other basis. The ruling was tantamount to an endorsement of guilt by association. In the jury’s mind, the distinction between consciousness of guilt and “an association between two people having an interest in the matter which is the subject of the trial” would be a distinction without a difference. The friendship between the two men had already been established and it was not in dispute. There could be nothing wrong in a person receiving a phone call from a friend and listening as the latter poured forth a matter of genuine concern to himself. 
     
      
       
      
    177 This appellant’s submissions should be accepted. Chami’s paramount purpose was concern for himself. Ghanem gave him a sympathetic ear, but did not adopt Chami’s inculpatory statements or otherwise implicate himself. The evidence was therefore not relevant to any case against Ghanem. It was certainly unfairly prejudicial to a degree that outweighed any probative force.  
     
      
       
      
    178 This situation is analogous to that of a person who visits a friend in gaol. It would be wrong to infer from this alone that the association was improper (cf Kawicki (1995) 82 A Crim R 191 at 194-5). 
     
      
       
      
    179 The Crown points out that the evidence was admitted before it was known whether Ghanem would give evidence. This does not really assist in resolving the issue of prejudice. In opposing the introduction of this material Ghanem’s counsel had offered to admit that he and Chami had gone to school together. There was already evidence about mobile phone discussions early in the evening in question and the fact that each man had the other’s number coded into his own phone. It follows that this Crown submission does not answer the issues of unfair prejudice or misuse of the material. 
     
      
       
      
    180 The risk of prejudice was not countered by warnings from the judge as to the inappropriate use of this material, the issue to which we turn immediately. 
     
      
       
      
    181 This ground is upheld. 
     
      
       
      
    182 We have found it unnecessary to consider the separate submission that any incriminatory tone or aspect of the Chami-Ghanem conversation (and of the cross-examination of Ghanem based on this evidence) may have been due to the fact that the focus of the conversation was a problem feared in relation to a different sexual assault then under police investigation. 
     
      
       
        
       Directions on telephone intercept evidence (Ghanem 4) 
        
       
      
    183 Despite the ruling that the telephone intercept evidence could not be used to show any consciousness of guilt by Ghanem, the Crown prosecutor addressed the jury in the following terms (Tr pp1121-2): 
     
      
       
        
         
         Of course in the break after [Chami] had admitted to having sex with her … there is this frantic call to Mohammed Ghanem. And, ladies and gentlemen, the Crown would submit to you that if … two good mates have together committed something of which they are not proud or something of a criminal nature and one is interviewed by police and makes certain admissions consistent with the crime, the very first person he is going to call is the person who was with him, his mate who was with him, and he rings Ghanem and he says “Ghanem, they've fucked me brother”. 
         
        
        
         
         Listen to it again. “What happened? Where are you?' “I'm at... everyone's name 
          [sic].  
         They know everything.” 
           
         Ghanem doesn't say they know everything about what? He says, “So what’s gunna happen”, and he goes straight down there on the double. And the arrangement of course is Chami doesn't have to tell Ghanem what happened, Ghanem knows, and obviously the conversation once he arrives is to get the heads together to make sure what is said is the same thing. 
         
        
        
         
        
       
      
    184 Ghanem correctly observes that this last sentence misrepresented the text of the intercepted conversation. He also submits that these comments made it even more important that the jury be directed against using the telephone intercept evidence to infer consciousness of guilt. No such directions were given. 
     
      
       
      
    185 In the written summary of facts the trial judge merely noted that the telephone intercept evidence was available against Ghanem. In the summing up itself the jury were told (SU138-9): 
     
      
       
        
         
         But the Crown case is that clearly here is Mr Chami, in the middle of an interview, ringing up Mr Ghanem to tell him they're both in trouble, the police are on to both of them and they had better get together at the library and have a chat about it.  
         
        
        
         
         And it turned out to be an inspired piece of prophecy, because indeed the police did speak to Mr Ghanem, and Mr Ghanem is here in court facing these charges. 
         
        
        
         
         On the Crown case the conversations are significant because they show two people, intimately connected with the events of this night, anxiously discussing what had occurred in the interview of one of them. Why would they discuss it? Because they had that common interest. 
         
        
        
         
         It is put on behalf of Mr Chami, and indeed on behalf of Mr Ghanem, that this was just a call between two friends; Mr Chami was merely passing on to his friend the fact that the police were going to charge him, he thought, with attempted murder; and it wasn’t because they were implicated in anything, it was just because they were two friends, and it’s the sort of discussion you would have between two friends. 
         
        
        
       
      
    186 Ghanem submits that these directions contradicted the limited basis upon which the telephone intercept evidence had been admitted against him; and they left the jury without any warning against using Chami's own inculpatory statements to attribute a consciousness of guilt on the part of Ghanem. 
     
      
       
      
    187 The Crown submits that the directions at SU138-9 set out above put the competing inferences that had been relied upon in the addresses of counsel. 
     
      
       
      
    188 In our view the directions exacerbated the situation created by the admission of the evidence against Ghanem. They also tended to concentrate on Chami’s perspective, without adverting to the hypothesis (supported by Ghanem’s evidence) that Ghanem was doing no more than giving his friend in trouble a sympathetic ear. Ghanem had not adopted anything said by Chami. This should have been put with emphasis and the jury should have been warned against using the information against him as indicating consciousness of guilt.  
     
      
       
      
    189 Notwithstanding rule 4 (which the Crown invokes) we would uphold this ground of appeal, especially since it is linked with Ghanem’s third ground of appeal. 
     
      
       
      
    190 Ghanem is entitled to a new trial. 
     
      
       
        
       Prosecutor’s comment on Chami’s failure to give evidence (Chami 5) 
        
       
      
    191 Chami’s sister-in-law gave character evidence in the trial. She was cross-examined about other issues, including the nature of the relationship between Chami and a young woman, Kyra. Chami had spoken to Kyra in an intercepted telephone call shortly after a lengthy and damaging ERISP on 13 October 2000, effectively coaching her as to the terms of a false alibi she should provide the police. 
     
      
       
      
    192 The cross-examination as to the length of the relationship included the following (Tr p1066, emphasis added): 
     
      
       
        
         
         Q. When do you say the relationship with Kyra started? 
          
         A. I don’t know the exact date or month. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. You said two years? 
          
         A. It’s been a couple of times. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. It’s 2002 now, May something or other? 
          
         A. I don’t know which month he met Kyra, it could have been a week before or a week after I don’t know the exact date. 
         
        
        
         
         Q. Two years. May 2000 right, so was it before then or after that? 
          
         A. Could be under two years.  
         Have you asked Mahmoud this question? 
         
        
        
         
         Q.  
         No and I don’t believe I will have the opportunity to do that so you tell me -- 
          
         A. -- I don’t know what day he met her. I know it’s a couple of years. 
         
        
        
       
      
    193 An application to discharge the jury was refused. 
     
      
       
      
    194 Section 20(2) of the Evidence Act relevantly prohibits a prosecutor from commenting on the failure of a defendant to give evidence in criminal proceedings. 
     
      
       
      
    195 The Crown prosecutor’s statement was made at a time after the jury had become aware that Chami would not be called as a witness. 
     
      
       
      
    196 In rejecting an application to discharge the jury, Judge Finnane held that the Crown prosecutor’s comment (“I won’t have the opportunity”):  
     
      
       
        
         
         … was a factual statement, as Ms Francis had indicated that she did not intend to call the accused. If the accused is not called, counsel present cannot cross-examine. That is our system of law. This was not a comment by the Prosecution on the failure of the accused to give evidence. It was a comment arising from the consequence that flows from the accused not giving evidence, namely, that she cannot cross-examine him. 
         
        
        
       
      
    197 The cross-examiner’s comment was unnecessary and unfortunate, but it did not infringe s20(2).  
     
      
       
      
    198 A contravention arises when the prosecutor refers to the fact that the accused has the right to give evidence but fails to give evidence. The question must depend on the words used and the circumstances in which they are used. As Higgins J said in Bataillard v The King (1907) 4 CLR 1282 at 1292: “the comment must be on the refraining – on the fact that he could have given evidence on oath and has not done so”. See also Peterson v The Queen (1979) 41 FLR 205. In our view, the prosecutor’s remarks did not go this far. 
     
      
       
      
    199 Appropriate instructions were later given to the jury regarding Chami’s failure to give evidence. 
     
      
       
      
    200 This ground fails. 
     
      
       
        
       Prosecutor’s address re warning (Mohammed Skaf Ground 5) 
       
      
    201 As indicated, the issue in relation to Counts 14 and 15 against Mohammed Skaf was that of identification. 
     
      
       
      
    202 The Crown prosecutor did not confine herself to addressing on the facts. The transcript of her address discloses that she ventured proleptically into the judge’s domain. She said (Tr pp1106-7, emphasis added): 
     
      
       
        
         
         Ladies and gentlemen, identification in the law is an interesting concept, and his Honour will give you many and detailed directions about identification and about how closely you have to examine and scrutinise identification evidence, and the law says,  
         the higher courts and the precedents in law tell us and oblige trial judges to give many warnings about identification. And, of course, many of those cases in which those warnings have been set down have involved cases where people get just fleeting looks at people who have committed a crime. 
          You might imagine say a bank robbery, if a person sees someone running out fast they get a bit of a look and they might think that they can identify someone, but you would have to look at that fairly closely because they don’t expect they are going to see a robber coming out, they just get a fleeting glance perhaps from the side, they have no real interest in the money the bank has lost, for example, and so they may not be in such a position as [Ms D] was.  
         
        
        
         
         [Ms D] identifies people who have actually had sexual intercourse with her and had their faces this close to her, right up close to her. She identifies people who she has known when things appear to be quite hopeful and she has seen them as things deteriorate into something disastrous for her. She saw them over a significant period of time, it was not just a fleeting glance as someone you might see running out of a shop or running away from a common assault in the street. She had got to know these people. She had spoken to them, she had put her trust in them, and in these cases she had seen them driving through streets, stopped at petrol stations, stopped at townhouses, and she had seen them there right up at close range having sexual intercourse with her. 
         
        
        
         
         So of course you must observe and listen to his Honour’s directions that he is required to give you, and in this and every identification case, because this is a special case you might think ladies and gentleman, this is a case where she has identified people she has spent a significant time with in various types of circumstances, including being so close as to be having sexual intercourse with them, and you might think the faces of those men, the men she identified and described so well, were galvanised upon her memory in the circumstances that she described. 
         
        
        
       
      
    203 Mohammed Skaf’s complaint on appeal is that counsel was effectively watering down the warning that would later be given by the trial judge, particularly by the reference to “higher courts and precedents”. 
     
      
       
      
    204 This ground has no merit. 
     
      
       
      
    205 There is no reason for thinking that the jury would have been deflected from their task. Counsel for the accused addressed later. And later still came the summing up in which the jury were given directions on the law and facts. 
     
      
       
      
    206 The Crown prosecutor was perfectly entitled to develop the argument that the complainant had significant opportunities to become familiar with Mohammed Skaf’s face and features. 
     
      
       
      
    207 It is also significant that the jury were sent out very shortly after the portion of the prosecutor’s address set out above. Counsel for two of the accused raised objections to recent remarks of the prosecutor, but no one raised the issue complained of in this ground of appeal. Rule 4 applies. 
     
      
       
      
    208 This ground fails. 
     
      
       
      
    209 It is convenient now to address the remaining complaints about the directions in the summing up. 
     
      
       
        
       Directions on standard of proof (Chami 1, Ghanem 6, Bilal Skaf 6, Mohammed Skaf 2) 
        
       
      
    210 The written Directions of Law given to the jury said: 
     
      
       
        
         
         Proof beyond reasonable doubt 
         
        
        
         
         The Crown must prove each of the elements of each charge in the case against each of the accused beyond reasonable doubt. The expression “beyond reasonable doubt” means what it says. It is the highest level of proof in our system of law. Each of you as jurors knows the meaning of this expression. 
         
        
        
       
      
    211 Early in his summing up the judge directed the jury as follows (SU 14-16, emphasis added): 
     
      
       
        
         
         Please remember each of you has to exercise your own judgment. No-one is entitled to bully you. No-one should make fun of you. You all have opinions that are equally important. All of you are entitled to express them and have them considered. When you come to decide something you can all have different  
         reasons 
          for deciding something. One of you may decide a particular witness is impressive because of one particular  
         reason 
         . The other may think that a witness gave very forthright evidence and I like that style. Another might say: Well, I thought that witness was telling the truth and have another  
         reason 
          for it altogether. When this witness said this and that that made sense, they are telling the truth. You can get two people coming to the same view, but approaching it in different ways. You do not all look at it in the same way. 
         
        
        
         
         In fact I will give you a document of what the elements of the particular offences are. What you have to be satisfied about beyond reasonable doubt is the actual ingredients of each offence. You do not have to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that every word [Ms D] said was true for example. What you have to be satisfied is, having heard all the evidence, you have to be satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt, that this particular charge is made out. You may have a doubt about some parts of this evidence or that evidence and yet still be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt. On the other hand, you may not be able to come to a conclusion that you are satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt. If you have a doubt  
         and it is based on reason 
          then you should give the benefit of that doubt to the accused person in whose case you are considering. 
         
        
        
         
         “Beyond reasonable doubt” is an expression meaning what it says. It is the highest form of proof known to the law. It does not mean “beyond reasonable doubt to the point of certainty”. It means “beyond reasonable doubt” it means what it says. “Beyond reasonable doubt”,  
         any doubt that is in fact reasonable 
         . 
         
        
        
       
      
    212 The appellants submit that these directions were erroneous as regards the bolded portions. Although no counsel took objection at trial, it is now submitted that the errors were fundamental and that a miscarriage ensued. 
     
      
       
      
    213 The Crown invokes rule 4. 
     
      
       
      
    214 No affidavit of trial counsel has been filed that might cast any light on the collective failure to raise any protest at trial. 
     
      
       
      
    215 There were many unexceptional references throughout the summing up as to the Crown’s onus and standard of proof. 
     
      
       
      
    216 Green v The Queen (1971) 126 CLR 28 is the reference point on this topic in Australian law. That decision and many following it have enjoined trial judges to refrain from expounding the criminal standard of proof. For a recent discussion see R v Southammavong [2003] NSWCCA 312. 
     
      
       
      
    217 It does not follow that every judicial gloss buffed onto the golden thread of the common law constitutes a miscarriage of justice. 
     
      
       
      
    218 The directions given to the jury about the meaning of “beyond reasonable doubt” in Green were erroneous in several respects and their harmful impact had to be considered in their unique context. Nevertheless, the High Court’s discussion in Green contains warnings that embody general principles.  
     
      
       
      
    219 The summing up on standard of proof in Green was held to be confusing (at 32) and to suggest of that “a comfortable satisfaction of the accused’s guilt would be enough” (at 33). However, a fundamental point of error was described in the following terms (at 32-3): 
     
      
       
        
         
         A reasonable doubt is a doubt which the particular jury entertain in the circumstances. Jurymen themselves set the standard of what is reasonable in the circumstances. It is that ability which is attributed to them which is one of the virtues of our mode of trial: to their task of deciding facts they bring to bear their experience and judgment. They are both unaccustomed and not required to submit their processes of mind to objective analysis of the kind proposed in the language of the judge in this case. “It is not their task to analyse their own mental processes”: Windeyer J,  
         Thomas v The Queen 
          [(1960) 102 CLR at p606)]. A reasonable doubt which a jury may entertain is not to be confined to a “rational doubt”, or a “doubt founded on reason” in the analytical sense or by such detailed processes as those proposed by the passage we have quoted from the summing up. Yet that is what they were directed to do in this case. 
         
        
       
      
    220 The offending direction in Green included the following (at 30): 
     
      
       
        
         
         And you may say “Well, how do I know when I have got to a stage of being satisfied about something beyond reasonable doubt?” and the answer to that is that it is when you have reached the stage that you either have no doubt at all, because if you have got no doubt at all you must have got rid of all reasonable doubts; or if there is something nagging in the back of your mind which makes you hesitate as to whether you are satisfied beyond reasonable doubt, you have got to try and take it out and identify this thing which is causing the hesitation, causing the doubt if you like, and you have a look at it and you try to assess it and you say to yourself is this doubt that is bothering me, does it proceed from reason; is it a rational doubt; is it something which raises a really sensible doubt; or is it a fantastic sort of doubt; is it something which arises from some prejudice that I may have; some quite unreasonable fear that I might go  
         [sic] 
          wrong; some perhaps reluctance to make an unpleasant finding. Well, if it is one of those doubts – merely one of those doubts, then of course it cannot be described as reasonable because it does not come from reason; it comes from something which is emotional or irrational or – at any rate it is not based upon reason, and if you have had a look at what is bothering you and you decide that it does proceed from something which is not reason but something fantastic or rising out of prejudice or one of these other things, then you should say to yourself, “The only doubt I’ve got is one which is not based on reason, I have therefore got rid of all doubts which are not based in reason, and the result of that is that I am satisfied beyond reasonable doubt, because the only things that are worrying me are things which I now assess after looking at them as not based in reason.” 
         
        
        
         
        
       
      
    221 The appellants submit that the directions in the present case share the fundamental defect exposed by the High Court in Green. They qualified the time-honoured standard by lessening it. 
     
      
       
      
    222 The vice of the present directions is said to be that the jury were invited to engage in “an analytic exercise dissecting such doubts as they may experience” (cf R v Ho (2002) 130 A Crim R 545 at 551 [27]). If any member of the jury entertained a reasonable doubt but was not able to identify the reason for that doubt then he or she would have been driven away from holding out for the acquittal to which the accused was entitled. The appellants cited R v Reeves (1992) 29 NSWLR 109 where Hunt CJ at CL (at 116-7) was critical of a trial judge who: 
     
      
       
        
         
         …invited the jury to ponder what exactly was meant by “reasonable”, and he suggested to them that the answer was not found in their own individual understanding of the work “reasonable”. 
         
        
       
      
    223 As to the fundamental consequence of a misdirection as to the onus of proof in a criminal trial, and the inapplicability of the proviso, the appellants cite Thomas v The Queen (1960) 102 CLR 581 at 588, 594, 596, 602 and 604. 
     
      
       
      
    224 The Crown submits, and we agree, that the early references to “reason” in the passage under examination are merely instructions to the jurors to exercise independent judgment. 
     
      
       
      
    225 The Crown further submits that the latter references to a doubt that “is based on reason” and “that is in fact reasonable” did not involve an invitation to the type of analytical approach admonished by the High Court. We agree. 
     
      
       
      
    226 The fleeting references to a “doubt based on reason” did not conjure up intricate diversions of the offending direction in Green. Nor did it entice the jury away from setting their own standard of reasonableness by minute subdivision and restatement of the time-honoured phrase. 
     
      
       
      
    227 In R v Li [2003] NSWCCA 386, a direction by the present trial judge referring to a “Doubt in your mind, and it’s a reasonable one” was held to be incorrect and inappropriate. Likewise a further reference to “a doubt based on reason”. The directions were then held to have caused the trial to miscarry. Despite the application of Rule 4 the misdirection was held to be fundamental and it contributed to an order quashing the conviction and ordering a new trial. In Li those misdirections were however compounded by being accompanied by an invitation to the jury to decide which of two cases (the complainant’s or the accused’s) was correct (see Dunford J at [72]. See also at [73]). There was also a separate misdirection on corroboration and the assessment of the complainant’s evidence that was found to be fundamentally flawed (see at [63]-[68], [76]). Li was decided after the judgment was reserved in the present appeals. It was drawn to this Court’s attention in a memorandum from senior counsel for Chami. It is persuasive but not conclusive on the present issue, because of the additional factors that contributed to the miscarriage there found established. 
     
      
       
      
    228 In R v Blanch, CCA unreported 17 August 1988 and R v Solomon, CCA unreported 15 November 1989, decisions to which our attention was drawn in a memorandum from senior counsel for Ghanem, this Court overturned convictions where the vices of the directions about standard of proof were that they contrasted beyond reasonable doubt with a state of “absolute certainty”. This comparative exercise was found to have put the wrong emphasis on the time-honoured direction. In Blanch the conviction was quashed even though redirection had not been sought. The vice attending Blanch and Solomon is not, however present in the directions complained of in the current appeals. 
     
      
       
      
    229 We do not endorse his Honour’s gloss. Its use should be discontinued. But the particular trial did not miscarry on this account. 
     
      
       
      
    230 These grounds fail.

    236 The appellants submit that these further directions would not have dispelled earlier confusion about the factual elements of the third count. We disagree.
